image.altText: A man with blue scrubs holding a blood pressure band

props.synopsis: Former Flinders Medical Centre nurse Geoffrey Leonard Atkins "lost his temper" and retaliated against a "highly vulnerable" patient who had thrown his head back into his face. A tribunal judgement banning the nurse from providing any health service, reveals the physically infirm patient was also ''hip-tossed'' into hospital bed railings.

title.children: 'No clinical or justifiable purpose': Nurse banned over patient headlock

image.altText: The blast furnace at the Whyalla steelworks.

props.synopsis: As well as the debt to SA Water, GFG Alliance has not made any royalty payments to the government this financial year, according to a senior public servant who says there are "concerns around solvency" for the troubled industrial plant.

title.children: Whyalla steelworks' owner GFG owes $15 million to SA Water

image.altText: The fascination that many Australians appear to have with the case of the missing Beaumont children is ethically fraught, as is the media's coverage of it.

props.synopsis: A former factory site linked to the 59-year-old the disappearance of the Beaumont children, which remains one of the nation's most baffling and tragic cold cases, will be searched a third time before being put up for sale, an SA MP says.

title.children: Beaumont children dig prompted by 'new information' about site linked to mystery

image.altText: A court building with arches

props.synopsis: The fees of a private investigator who charged more than $250,000 for his "unnecessary" work in a medical negligence lawsuit, despite having no relevant qualifications, were "excessive", a South Australian Supreme Court has found.

title.children: SA government not liable for 'excessive' private investigator fees in medical negligence claim

image.altText: An artist's impression of an overhead view of the proposed Whyalla hydrogen project.

props.synopsis: Four years after the South Australian government's bold and ambitious — but very much hypothetical — hydrogen power plant was first announced, there have been inauspicious developments concerning its future.

title.children: Will SA's $593m hydrogen power plant proposal vanish into thin air?

image.altText: A police officer, wearing protective clothing, walks in a backyard behind police tape.

props.synopsis: A detective has told an inquest into the death of a mother of two that there was no evidence to suggest or exclude a homicide despite a second police investigation.

title.children: Inquest begins into death of woman found in NSW backyard

image.altText: A sign that reads Renmark High School with the SA government logo at the bottom.

props.synopsis: The identification of three external providers approved to operate in the state's public schools follows a presentation given to year 9 students last year that allegedly included bestiality references.

title.children: SA school given list of approved sex education providers

image.altText: A woman with dark red hair pays for her coffee at a counter in a cafe.

props.synopsis: Small business owners in popular holiday towns say phones and EFTPOS often drop out during peak season, causing a real impact on their sales.

title.children: When the tourists pour in, the internet drops out in holiday towns

image.altText: Two construction workers work on steel beams with the blue sky behind them

props.synopsis: However desperate the situation might seem, cities around the world have shown that a housing crisis can be solved quickly with sufficient political will.

title.children: Auckland's housing crisis changed quickly. Australia could do the same

image.altText: A middle-aged woman with grey hair in a ponytail holding papers at a table

props.synopsis: High breast density elevates a woman's cancer risk, but unlike other countries, Australia doesn't routinely report this information.

title.children: 'Cancer might be missed': Australia lags on breast density reporting

image.altText: Kansas City Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes looks worries during Super Bowl LIX.

props.synopsis: Patrick Mahomes's Super Bowl heroics had him in the GOAT conversation last year, but the sentiments were far less flattering after the Chiefs' thumping loss to Philadelphia.

title.children: 'I let y'all down': Mahomes vows to come back better after horror Super Bowl

image.altText: A person's silhouette stands in front of a multicoloured projected graphic of a Bitcoin token.

props.synopsis: Cryptocurrencies are notoriously volatile and some economists say they have no intrinsic value, but that hasn't stopped some lenders from offering loans if Bitcoin or Ethereum are used as collateral.

title.children: Rise in crypto lending sparks financial 'contagion' concerns

image.altText: Anthony Albanese during QT

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has an urgent discussion scheduled with US President Donald Trump as he signals plans for sweeping 25 per cent tariffs on steel and aluminium imports.

title.children: PM to speak with Trump after president flags steel tariffs

image.altText: Dr Brian Morton GP is seen in his clinicdoing vaccination prep .Set up pics as an example of what will happen when vaccinations start at your local GP’S Clinic. Sydney. February 24  2021. (Image_Brendan Esposito)  - Dr Brian Morton GP

props.synopsis: New bulk-billing data shows a slight improvement to 77.5 per cent of GP visits being bulk-billed. The Royal Australian College of GPs says it has a plan to restore that rate to pre-COVID levels.

title.children: Doctors pitch plan to lift bulk-billing rate to 85 per cent

image.altText: A group watch on as two women do a role-play tugging an arm.

props.synopsis: The US foreign aid freeze could lead to more people being trafficked into online fraud compounds in Asia and more Americans and Australians being scammed, experts say.

title.children: 'A win for traffickers' as US freezes anti-crime funds

image.altText: Aboriginal man with grey hair and beard looks at the camera sitting outside a brick home

props.synopsis: The federal government's announced its annual plan to try close the gap between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians. The strategy is based on last year's report that found adult incarceration was worsening.

title.children: 'Drunk at primary school': Behind one of Australia's biggest reports

props.synopsis: Around-the-clock coverage of news events as they break, at home and abroad.

title.children: Watch: News Channel

image.altText: A bouncer standing next to an ID scanner takes ID off patron.

props.synopsis: Privacy advocates and cybersecurity experts say the growing use of ID scanning at venues raises the risk of personal data breaches. They argue a more ambitious overhaul of privacy laws is needed.

title.children: A photo of your passport, face, and a biometric match — all to get a drink

image.altText: Three Caritas volunteers in red jumpers and blue facemasks prepare food in a kitchen.

props.synopsis: "The ruthless and chaotic way this callous decision is being implemented threatens the lives and dignity of millions," Caritas Internationalis said in a statement.

title.children: Trump's foreign aid cuts 'catastrophic', says Catholic church's charity arm

image.altText: Emergency service workers working to free people from a bus which is upside down

props.synopsis: The fire department said the driver lost control of the bus and collided with several small vehicles before plunging over the precipice.

title.children: At least 51 dead after bus plunges into ravine in Guatemala

image.altText: JULIE INMAN GRANT TV INTERVIEW

props.synopsis: Australia's e-Safety commissioner has given a frank assessment of billionaire Elon Musk, whose "unrelenting vitriol" has seen death threats directed at her and her family.

title.children: 'Unelected bureaucrat': e-Safety commissioner unleashes on Elon Musk

image.altText: A woman with dark brown hair and glasses in a green coat, smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: It's one of the most controversial books published this century. Author Nikki Gemmell reveals the story behind her bestseller, The Bride Stripped Bare.

title.children: 'I lost a lot of cred': Nikki Gemmell on The Bride Stripped Bare scandal

image.altText: Supporters with Woodside protesters

props.synopsis: Three climate activists have been fined for attempting to spray political messages on Woodside boss Meg O'Neill's home, after a Perth magistrate told the trio they had crossed a line by targeting her personally.

title.children: Climate activists shown less leniency after targeting Woodside boss's home

image.altText: A render of apartment buildings over a city skyline.

props.synopsis: The solution to Australia's housing crisis could be building out but government infrastructure can't keep up. It could also be building up but Nimbyism is looking to put a stop to that.

title.children: Is the great Australian dream broken beyond repair?

props.synopsis: Emergency services have rescued more than 20 people from flash flooding across Sydney after the city was drenched by a fast-moving thunderstorm that brought wild weather to large parts of NSW.

title.children: Sydneysiders rescued from flash flooding as wild storm drenches NSW

image.altText: The tail of a Virgin Australia plane on the tarmac, with other planes lines up behind it.

props.synopsis: Ilaisa Tanoa Degei, 24, was charged with one count of rape and one count of sexual assault after he allegedly attacked the 21-year-old flight attendant.

title.children: Man accused of raping Virgin crew member in Fiji granted bail

image.altText: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, is escorted into a hall by monks holding his hands

props.synopsis: The Chinese government says it is open to the Dalai Lama returning home after more than 65 years in exile in India if the leader of Tibetan Buddhism can "return to the right path".

title.children: More than 65 years ago the Dalai Lama left Tibet. These are China's conditions for his return

image.altText: A redheaded young man wearing sunglasses sings into a microphone in front of an Indian police officer.

props.synopsis: Pop megastar Ed Sheeran denies he unlawfully serenaded the Indian public after police said he lacked the necessary permission to play and abruptly cut off his street performance.

title.children: Ed Sheeran performance cut short mid-song by Indian police

image.altText: A juvenile coatal taipan snake crawls through grass.

props.synopsis: A woman who was bitten on the back steps of her home is being treated for loss of eyesight and neurological problems.

title.children: Taipan bite leaves north Queensland woman in intensive care

image.altText: Cassius pictured at a horse track

props.synopsis: The death of Perth schoolboy Cassius Turvey was "the end point of a complex series of events" that had "nothing to do with him", WA's Supreme Court is told at the start of the trial of the four people accused of his murder.

title.children: Cassius Turvey's murder trial told 'petty grievances' led to his death

image.altText: A checkout stacked with groceries including tomato sauce and shampoo

props.synopsis: Essential items in remote stores will be price-locked as part of a $50 million federal scheme to slash the cost of groceries in the bush, which can soar to double the price of what's available in capital cities.

title.children: In the bush, groceries can cost twice as much as in the city. Here's why

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie with sunglasses and a covid face mask

props.synopsis: Former NSW Police officer, Jordan Weston, has been sentenced to multiple community corrections orders after pleading guilty to charges of assault, stalking and intimidation of his ex-partner.

title.children: Former senior officer's behaviour 'breach of trust', judge says in DV sentence

image.altText: A soldier wearing camouflage lies by a tree surrounded by snow in a photo taken by a drone above him.

props.synopsis: Inside a secret bunker with the Ukrainians launching kamikaze drones at Russian troops.

title.children: This Russian soldier has been spotted by a Ukrainian drone. He has nowhere to hide

image.altText: Older woman wearing blue shirt and jeans looks out kitchen windows with dull light coming in and a cupboard behind her

props.synopsis: Two-thirds of retired renters are in poverty, according to new analysis from the Grattan Institute, with calls for the major parties to increase Rent Assistance to ease the burden.

title.children: For a decade, Lyn has paid her rent, but she's now living in poverty
